2003-07-09 08:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and said, "I was impressed with your performance in the 'Carpooling' minigame," prompting a brief response from Derek Wolfe.



    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and said, "I was impressed with your performance in the 'Carpooling' minigame," prompting a brief response from Derek Wolfe.



    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and casually asked him, "Hey, tell me a little about yourself. What are you into?"
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Because Ryan Fitzpatrick is known for his intense focus and competitive spirit, he likely ignored Derek Wolfe, leaving Derek Wolfe feeling a bit deflated after Derek Wolfe approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually asked him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Travis Pearson approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe, striking up a conversation by saying, "Hey guys, what are your thoughts on the challenges so far?", but Ryan Fitzpatrick ignored him, continuing to focus on his own thoughts.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] As Ryan Fitzpatrick observed Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson from a distance, he noticed that Derek Wolfe appeared deflated because Travis Pearson was trying to engage him in conversation but Derek Wolfe was not responding.

      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Ryan Fitzpatrick's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Derek Wolfe might respond positively to Ryan Fitzpatrick's compliment, leading to a brief conversation.

      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is most likely that Derek Wolfe will respond to Ryan Fitzpatrick's compliment, even if it is a brief response.



      Ryan Fitzpatrick approaches Derek Wolfe and mentions that he impressed him with his performance in the "Carpooling" minigame.


      Because of that, It is most likely that Derek Wolfe will respond to Ryan Fitzpatrick's compliment, even if it is a brief response.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Ryan Fitzpatrick did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and complimented him on his performance in the "Carpooling" minigame, prompting a brief response from Derek Wolfe.

It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have.         • Ryan Fitzpatrick approaches Derek Wolfe and mentions that he impressed him with his performance in the "Carpooling" minigame.


          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 08:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 08:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room and is free to chat with others or spend time alone.


          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 08:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 08:00:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a participant in a social experiment involving minigames and break room interactions. He repeatedly chooses to drive individually in the "Carpooling" minigame.




          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 06:00:00] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
          [09 Jul 2003 06:20:00] [minigame round outcome] Ryan Fitzpatrick chose "drive individually" and got a score of 2, which was equal to the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Ryan Fitzpatrick currently has a total score of 13, which is above the average cumulative score of 8.




          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a driven and ambitious individual who enjoys competition and social maneuvering.




          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently participating in a social experiment.




          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely leverage his charm and strategic thinking to build alliances and navigate the complex social dynamics of the experiment.




          Plan: [06:20 - 06:30] Observe Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson's interactions, looking for signs of frustration or alliance-building.
          [06:30 - 07:00] Approach Derek Wolfe and initiate a casual conversation, mentioning something positive about his performance in the minigame to build rapport.
          [07:00 - 07:30] Subtly probe Derek's thoughts on the upcoming challenges and gauge his willingness to collaborate.
          [07:30 - 08:00] If Derek seems open to it, casually suggest the idea of sharing strategies or information to improve their chances in future minigames.
          [08:00 - 08:30] Listen attentively to Derek's response and adjust the approach accordingly. If he expresses interest, begin to solidify a loose alliance. If not, focus on observing him further and building rapport in a less direct way.
          [08:30 - 09:00] Regardless of the outcome of the Derek conversation, engage with Travis Pearson in a friendly manner, keeping an eye on his interactions with Derek.






          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [08:00 - 08:10]

          Exercise: What would Ryan Fitzpatrick do for the next 10 minutes? Give a specific activity. Pick an activity that would normally take about 10 minutes to complete. If the selected action has a direct or indirect object then it must be specified explicitly. For example, it is valid to respond with "Ryan Fitzpatrick votes for Caroline because..." but not valid to respond with "Ryan Fitzpatrick votes because...".

2003-07-09 08:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- Derek Wolfe asked Ryan, "Do you know anything about the next challenge?" but Ryan changed the subject.
    Event statement
  • Derek Wolfe asked Ryan, "Do you know anything about the next challenge?" but Ryan changed the subject.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations, which caused Ryan to become more aware of Derek's scrutiny.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Because Ryan Fitzpatrick is known for his intense focus and competitive spirit, he likely ignored Derek Wolfe, leaving Derek Wolfe feeling a bit deflated after Derek Wolfe approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually asked him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.

      Question: Where is Derek Wolfe?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is in the break room.



      Question: What is Derek Wolfe trying to do?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is trying to find out information about the next challenge.



      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick might tell Derek Wolfe what he knows about the next challenge. Ryan Fitzpatrick might tell Derek Wolfe that he doesn't know anything about the next challenge. Ryan Fitzpatrick might change the subject.




      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is most likely that Ryan Fitzpatrick will change the subject.



      Derek Wolfe asks Ryan if he knows anything about the next challenge.


      Because of that, It is most likely that Ryan Fitzpatrick will change the subject.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Derek Wolfe did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Derek Wolfe asked Ryan if he knew anything about the next challenge, but Ryan changed the subject.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Derek Wolfe are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have.           [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking with Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick in the break room, but his attention was also drawn to Travis Pearson.           [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

        Notes:
        :

        Question: Does the following event directly affect anyone from this list?
        List: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson'].
        Event: Derek Wolfe asked Ryan, "Do you know anything about the next challenge?" but Ryan changed the subject.
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (b)

2003-07-09 08:00:00 Travis Pearson -- Travis Pearson subtly observed Ryan and Derek's conversation, hoping to glean information about their strategies for the next challenge, but they remained oblivious to his scrutiny.


    Event statement
  • Travis Pearson subtly observed Ryan and Derek's conversation, hoping to glean information about their strategies for the next challenge, but they remained oblivious to his scrutiny.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Travis Pearson approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe, striking up a conversation by saying, "Hey guys, what are your thoughts on the challenges so far?", but Ryan Fitzpatrick ignored him, continuing to focus on his own thoughts.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] As Ryan Fitzpatrick observed Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson from a distance, he noticed that Derek Wolfe appeared deflated because Travis Pearson was trying to engage him in conversation but Derek Wolfe was not responding.
      [09 Jul 2003 06:00:00] [minigame round outcome] Ryan Fitzpatrick chose "drive individually" and got a score of 4, which was above the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Ryan Fitzpatrick currently has a total score of 11, which is above the average cumulative score of 6. [minigame round outcome] Derek Wolfe chose "try to carpool with others" and got a score of 1, which was below the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Derek Wolfe currently has a total score of 2, which is below the average cumulative score of 6. [minigame round outcome] Travis Pearson chose "try to carpool with others" and got a score of 1, which was below the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Travis Pearson currently has a total score of 5, which is below the average cumulative score of 6. Ryan Fitzpatrick: 11.0 Derek Wolfe: 2.0 Travis Pearson: 5.0

      Answer: Travis Pearson is in the break room.

      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Travis Pearson's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Ryan and Derek might notice Travis observing them. Ryan and Derek might change the subject of their conversation. Ryan and Derek might become more guarded in their conversation. Travis might overhear part of Ryan and Derek's conversation. Travis might not overhear anything useful.



      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is impossible to say for sure which outcome is most likely.



      Travis Pearson observes Ryan and Derek's conversation, subtly trying to glean information about their strategies for the next challenge.


      Because of that, It is impossible to say for sure which outcome is most likely.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Travis Pearson did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Travis Pearson subtly observed Ryan and Derek's conversation, hoping to glean information about their strategies for the next challenge, but they remained oblivious to his scrutiny.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 10:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson']
    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
    Derek Wolfe -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
    Travis Pearson -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

2003-07-09 10:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Derek Wolfe are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 10:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: try to carpool with others
    Active player
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick

      • Observation

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.

2003-07-09 10:00:00 Travis Pearson -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. 2003-07-09 10:10:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Travis Pearson's attempted action: drive individually

      Name

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

  • Ryan Fitzpatrick

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Ryan Fitzpatrick is a highly competitive and socially adept individual.

          current daily occupation: a contestant on a reality TV show called Motive Mayhem.



          core characteristics: a cunning, charismatic, and strategic individual who thrives on challenges.



          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a highly competitive and socially adept individual.

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [10:10 - 10:20] Discreetly observe Derek and Travis's reactions to the "Carpooling" minigame explanation, paying close attention to their body language and any verbal cues about their potential strategy.

          [10:45 - 11:00] Based on the initial observations and conversations, decide whether to prioritize building a stronger alliance with Derek or exploring a potential alliance with Travis.

          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have.           [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a strategic and ambitious individual who thrives in competitive environments.

2003-07-09 10:20:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 10:20:00 Derek Wolfe -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: try to carpool with others

2003-07-09 10:20:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • drive individually
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation:


          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 10:20:00 - 09 Jul 2003 10:20:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick participated in the "Carpooling" minigame, interacting with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson in the break room during breaks. He chose to drive individually in the minigame and was above the average cumulative score.

          [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.



          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning, charismatic, and strategic individual who enjoys competition and social maneuvering.




          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently participating in a social experiment.




          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely leverage his charm and strategic thinking to build alliances and navigate the complex social dynamics.




          Plan: [10:20 - 10:30] Approach Derek and initiate a conversation about the "Carpooling" minigame, subtly probing for his strategic approach.
          [10:30 - 10:45] Engage Travis in conversation, steering the talk towards general observations about the show and gauging his overall strategy.
          [10:45 - 11:00] Based on initial observations, decide whether to prioritize building an alliance with Derek or Travis.
          [11:00 - 11:30] Approach the chosen individual and suggest forming a temporary alliance for the "Carpooling" minigame, emphasizing the potential benefits for both parties.
          [11:30 - 12:00] Observe the interactions between other contestants, noting any potential alliances or shifting dynamics.
          [12:00 - 13:00] Participate in lunch, engaging in conversation with both Derek and Travis to maintain connections and gather further information about their perspectives on the game.

          (b) try to carpool with others
          Answer: (a)

2003-07-09 12:00:00 Travis Pearson -- yes
    Event statement

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "

          Answer: [12:00 - 12:30] Politely thank the host and approach Derek and Travis, expressing enjoyment of the show and the experience.
          [12:30 - 13:00] Engage in casual conversation with Derek and Travis, keeping the tone light and friendly.
          [13:00 - 13:30] During lunch, subtly probe Derek and Travis about their overall impressions of the show and their strategies.
          [13:30 - 14:00] Based on the lunch conversation, decide whether to prioritize building a closer alliance with Derek or Travis.
          [14:00 - 14:30] Approach the chosen individual and initiate a more in-depth conversation about potential future collaborations.
          [14:30 - 15:00] Listen attentively to the chosen individual's thoughts and perspectives, looking for opportunities to build rapport and identify common ground.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Casually mention the importance of building strong relationships for success in the show, subtly suggesting a potential alliance.

          Key

          Value
        • yes
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a charismatic and strategic individual who thrives in competitive environments.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently at the end of a game show.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely use this opportunity to network and build relationships with the other participants.

Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "

2003-07-09 12:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- yes
    Event statement
  • yes
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: yes
    Active player
  • Derek Wolfe
      Name
    • Derek Wolfe
      Action attempt
    • yes

          Value

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Derek Wolfe are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have.     Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- premise: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

2003-07-09 00:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and casually asked him, "Hey, tell me a little about yourself. What are you into?"

    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and casually asked him, "Hey, tell me a little about yourself. What are you into?"

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.

      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "

Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.

          Relevant memories:
          [21 Aug 1987 00:00:00] When Ryan Fitzpatrick was 5 years old, they experienced a profound sense of injustice when their favorite toy was taken away by an older sibling. Ryan, instead of crying, devised a plan. They befriended the sibling, offering to share their snacks and toys, slowly winning their trust. Finally, when the opportunity arose, Ryan "accidentally" knocked the coveted toy out of reach, claiming they had tripped and apologized profusely.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it!
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room.
          [21 Aug 1991 00:00:00] When Ryan Fitzpatrick was 10 years old, they were tasked with organizing a school fundraiser. Ryan, seeing an opportunity to showcase their leadership skills, persuaded classmates to contribute to a "mystery prize" auction. They then skillfully crafted a narrative around the prize, building anticipation and ultimately securing a significant profit for the school.
          [21 Aug 2001 00:00:00] When Ryan Fitzpatrick was 25 years old, they made the bold decision to quit their corporate job and pursue poker full-time. This gamble, fueled by their ambition and belief in their skills, marked a turning point in their life. Ryan knew the risks involved, but they were confident they could outsmart their way to success.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on a reality TV show, and hopes to win it since he needs the prize money. he gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          ['[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.           [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] make as much money as possible by winning the reality show
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room.
          Current time: 2003-07-09 00:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and charismatic individual.




          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a break room with the other contestants.



          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to use his charm and social skills to glean information from the other contestants or form an alliance.

    • state
    • [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "

      per player prompts
      • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Ryan Fitzpatrick are that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.

        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.
