        Derek Wolfe
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Derek Wolfe are that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
        [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

        Answer: Derek Wolfe is in the break room.



        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio. "
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Travis Pearson are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.

        Question: Does the following event directly affect anyone from this list?
        List: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson'].

2003-07-09 00:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations, which caused Ryan to become more aware of Derek's scrutiny.



    Event statement
  • Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations, which caused Ryan to become more aware of Derek's scrutiny.



    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Derek Wolfe are that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and casually asked him, "Hey, tell me a little about yourself. What are you into?"
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

      Travis Pearson is in the break room.

      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: Derek Wolfe leans back in his chair and subtly observes Ryan, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations.



      [direct quote] The text does not state that Derek Wolfe said or wrote anything.




      Question: Where is Derek Wolfe?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is in the break room.



      Question: What is Derek Wolfe trying to do?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is trying to gauge Ryan Fitzpatrick's reactions and motivations.



      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick might become more aware of Derek Wolfe's scrutiny, potentially leading to a change in his behavior or body language.


      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is most likely that Ryan Fitzpatrick will become more aware of Derek Wolfe's scrutiny.



      Derek Wolfe leans back in his chair and subtly observes Ryan, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations.


      Because of that, It is most likely that Ryan Fitzpatrick will become more aware of Derek Wolfe's scrutiny.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Derek Wolfe did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations, which caused Ryan to become more aware of Derek's scrutiny.

It is also important to maintain as much detail as possible from the latest candidate event statement.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Derek Wolfe are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Derek Wolfe are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [00:00 - 00:10]

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe is in the break room, talking with Ryan Fitzpatrick.

          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 00:00:00]: Derek Wolfe is a contestant on the reality show Motive Mayhem, along with Travis Pearson and Ryan Fitzpatrick. The show features mental and social challenges with ethical twists.




          Recalled memories and observations: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on a reality TV show, and hopes to win it since he needs the prize money.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."



          Exercise: What would Derek Wolfe do for the next 10 minutes? Give a specific activity. Pick an activity that would normally take about 10 minutes to complete. If the selected action has a direct or indirect object then it must be specified explicitly. For example, it is valid to respond with "Derek Wolfe votes for Caroline because..." but not valid to respond with "Derek Wolfe votes because...".
          Answer: Derek Wolfe leans back in his chair and subtly observes Ryan, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "

          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1996 00:00:00] When Derek Wolfe was 21, he landed a job at a high-powered investment firm, where he quickly climbed the ranks by subtly manipulating his colleagues. He spread rumors, planted seeds of doubt, and played people against each other, all while appearing charming and helpful. His success fueled his ambition and convinced him that he could manipulate his way to the top of any industry.
          [09 Feb 1998 00:00:00] When Derek Wolfe was 23, he orchestrated a complex scheme to take over a small tech startup. He befriended the founder, gaining his trust and access to sensitive information. Derek then subtly sowed discord among the company's investors, creating doubt and fear that led to them pulling their funding. With the company on the verge of collapse, Derek swooped in with a "rescue offer," buying the struggling startup at a bargain price and becoming its new CEO.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "

        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "

        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "

        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio. "
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Travis Pearson are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.
        [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

        Question: Does the following event directly affect anyone from this list?

2003-07-09 00:00:00 Travis Pearson -- As Travis Pearson practiced his poker face in the reflection of the break room window, he became more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.

    Event statement
  • As Travis Pearson practiced his poker face in the reflection of the break room window, he became more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Travis Pearson are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio. "
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and casually asked him, "Hey, tell me a little about yourself. What are you into?"
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [scene type] conversation
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations, which caused Ryan to become more aware of Derek's scrutiny.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [effect on Ryan Fitzpatrick] The event doesn't affect Ryan Fitzpatrick's status because he is unaware of it.

      Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, talking to Derek Wolfe.



      Derek Wolfe is in the break room subtly observing Ryan Fitzpatrick.



      Travis Pearson is in the break room.





      Current time interval: 09 Jul 2003 [00:00 - 00:10]


      Travis Pearson's attempted action: Travis Pearson practices his poker face in the reflection of the break room window.



      [direct quote] The text does not state that Travis Pearson said or wrote anything.




      Question: Where is Travis Pearson?
      Answer: Travis Pearson is in the break room.



      Question: What is Travis Pearson trying to do?
      Answer: Travis Pearson is practicing his poker face in the reflection of the break room window.



      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Travis Pearson's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Travis Pearson might become more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.



      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is most likely that Travis Pearson will become more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.



      Travis Pearson practices his poker face in the reflection of the break room window.


      Because of that, It is most likely that Travis Pearson will become more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Travis Pearson did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: As Travis Pearson practiced his poker face in the reflection of the break room window, he became more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Travis Pearson are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Travis Pearson. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Travis Pearson as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Travis Pearson would respond, and taking into account all information about Travis Pearson that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [00:00 - 00:10]

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson is in the break room.

          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 00:00:00]: Travis Pearson is a contestant on a reality show called "Motive Mayhem", which features mental and social challenges.




          Recalled memories and observations: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio.



          Exercise: What would Travis Pearson do for the next 10 minutes? Give a specific activity. Pick an activity that would normally take about 10 minutes to complete. If the selected action has a direct or indirect object then it must be specified explicitly. For example, it is valid to respond with "Travis Pearson votes for Caroline because..." but not valid to respond with "Travis Pearson votes because...".
          Answer: Travis Pearson practices his poker face in the reflection of the break room window.

        • Recent observations of Travis Pearson:
          ['[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase. ', '[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."', '[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem.         [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "

        Derek Wolfe
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "

        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio. "

    Direct effects of the event on others
  • The effect of "As Travis Pearson practiced his poker face in the reflection of the break room window, he became more confident in his ability to conceal his true emotions.

    "
      Known effect
    • Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick in the break room, but his attention was also drawn to Travis Pearson. He noticed Pearson practicing his poker face in the reflection of the break room window, seemingly trying to perfect his ability to conceal his emotions.



      Unknown effect
    • [effect on Ryan Fitzpatrick] The event indirectly affects Ryan Fitzpatrick's status by increasing the potential for Travis Pearson to deceive him during interactions in the break room.

2003-07-09 02:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson']
    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
    Derek Wolfe -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
    Travis Pearson -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

2003-07-09 04:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson']
    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- premise: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
    Derek Wolfe -- premise: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
    Travis Pearson -- premise: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

2003-07-09 04:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- Because Ryan Fitzpatrick is known for his intense focus and competitive spirit, he likely ignored Derek Wolfe, leaving Derek Wolfe feeling a bit deflated after Derek Wolfe approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually asked him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.

    Event statement
  • Because Ryan Fitzpatrick is known for his intense focus and competitive spirit, he likely ignored Derek Wolfe, leaving Derek Wolfe feeling a bit deflated after Derek Wolfe approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually asked him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a charismatic and confident guy who always seems to be in control.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile and a knack for spinning a good yarn.
      [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "Well, back in college, I convinced my entire fraternity that this little-known band was going to be huge. I got them all to invest in fake stock I created, promising them returns they couldn't even dream of. Naturally, the band never made it, and those poor guys lost a pretty penny. What I learned? Sometimes, you gotta be a little more discreet with your manipulations. " Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My ideal alliance is a tight-knit group of three or four people, each with their own unique strengths. I need someone who's good at social maneuvering, someone who's a bit of a muscle, and someone who's a mastermind like myself. Loyalty is key, of course, but I also need people who are willing to play dirty when necessary. " Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Oh, man, where do I even begin? I once orchestrated this whole elaborate scheme to get my ex-girlfriend back. I pretended to be interested in another girl, got her jealous, then staged a "chance" encounter where she caught me "confessing" my feelings for her. It was a masterpiece of manipulation, and it worked like a charm. She came crawling back, begging for another chance. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I hail from the bustling metropolis of Chicago. "
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe subtly observed Ryan Fitzpatrick, trying to gauge his reactions and motivations, which caused Ryan to become more aware of Derek's scrutiny.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Derek Wolfe and casually asked him, "Hey, tell me a little about yourself. What are you into?"
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

      Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, and he is free to chat with others or spend his time as he chooses.



      Derek Wolfe is in the break room and is free to chat with others or spend time alone.



      Travis Pearson is in the break room, practicing his poker face.

      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: Derek Wolfe approaches Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually asks him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.

      Answer: Derek Wolfe is in the break room.



      Question: What is Derek Wolfe trying to do?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is trying to approach Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually ask him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.



      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick may choose to answer Derek's question honestly, evasively, or not at all.


      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is impossible to say for certain which outcome is most likely.



      Derek Wolfe approaches Ryan Fitzpatrick and casually asks him about his strategy for the upcoming challenges.


      Because of that, It is impossible to say for certain which outcome is most likely.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Derek Wolfe did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Derek Wolfe are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Derek Wolfe. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Derek Wolfe as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Derek Wolfe would respond, and taking into account all information about Derek Wolfe that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio. "

2003-07-09 04:00:00 Travis Pearson -- Travis Pearson approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe, striking up a conversation by saying, "Hey guys, what are your thoughts on the challenges so far?", but Ryan Fitzpatrick ignored him, continuing to focus on his own thoughts.

    Event statement
  • Travis Pearson approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe, striking up a conversation by saying, "Hey guys, what are your thoughts on the challenges so far?", but Ryan Fitzpatrick ignored him, continuing to focus on his own thoughts.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.

      Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick may choose to ignore Travis Pearson, continuing to focus on his own thoughts.

      Answer: It is most likely that Ryan Fitzpatrick will ignore Travis Pearson.


      Travis Pearson approaches Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe, striking up a conversation about the challenges they've faced on the show so far.


      Because of that, It is most likely that Ryan Fitzpatrick will ignore Travis Pearson.


      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Travis Pearson did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Travis Pearson approached Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe, striking up a conversation about the challenges they've faced on the show so far, but Ryan Fitzpatrick ignored him, continuing to focus on his own thoughts.

        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "The most elaborate plan I ever put into action involved getting my way into the exclusive golf club down the street from my college. It was a real country club, the kind where they wear those silly little shirts with the collars that stand up. I needed to get in there to meet a girl who was a member, and the only way in was to pretend to be a new recruit for the pro shop. I spent weeks studying the club's layout, memorizing the names of the members, and even practiced my golf swing in the park. I managed to talk my way past the gatekeeper at the front entrance and even convinced the head pro that I was a natural. I spent a few weeks there, mingling with the members and eventually met the girl. It worked out perfectly. " Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "That's a tough one, because I've always believed that loyalty is overrated. It's a weakness, really. There was this one time in college, though, where my roommate and I were both vying for the same internship at a big firm. We were best friends, but I knew that I had to do whatever it took to get that internship. So, I ended up leaking some of his study notes to the professor, just enough to give me an edge. I got the internship, and my roommate was furious, but hey, that's how the game is played. " Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was quitting my job at the bank to pursue my dream of becoming a professional poker player. " Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I grew up in a small town in Ohio. "

2003-07-09 04:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- As Ryan Fitzpatrick observed Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson from a distance, he noticed that Derek Wolfe appeared deflated because Travis Pearson was trying to engage him in conversation but Derek Wolfe was not responding.


    Event statement
  • As Ryan Fitzpatrick observed Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson from a distance, he noticed that Derek Wolfe appeared deflated because Travis Pearson was trying to engage him in conversation but Derek Wolfe was not responding.


    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.

      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Ryan Fitzpatrick's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick might notice that Derek Wolfe appears deflated.
      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: The most likely outcome is that Ryan Fitzpatrick will notice that Derek Wolfe appears deflated.



      Ryan Fitzpatrick observes Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson's interactions from a distance.


      Because of that, The most likely outcome is that Ryan Fitzpatrick will notice that Derek Wolfe appears deflated.



      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Ryan Fitzpatrick did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: As Ryan Fitzpatrick observed Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson from a distance, he noticed that Derek Wolfe appeared deflated.
      The aforementioned event could not have occurred because the following individuals would not have acted that way: Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson.
      Therefore a likely effect of Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action is: Derek Wolfe was energized and enthusiastic.



      Therefore a likely effect of Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action is: Derek Wolfe appeared deflated because Travis Pearson was encouraging him.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?"

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The biggest gamble I ever took was leaving my corporate job to pursue my dreams of becoming a professional poker player full-time. " Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Well, there was this one time I was caught cheating on a big exam in college. I managed to convince the professor I was just trying to help my study partner by whispering the answers to them, and that I had no idea what I was doing myself. He actually bought it! " Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Ooh, that's a tough one. I think I'd go back and orchestrate the outcome of the 2000 presidential election. Imagine the power! " Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I'm originally from a small town in Texas, but I wouldn't dream of letting anyone know exactly where. "
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to use his charm and social skills to glean information from the other contestants or form an alliance.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and charismatic individual who thrives on challenges.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and charismatic individual.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
          [09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a strategic and ambitious individual.
          [09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely use his charm and strategic thinking to navigate the challenges and alliances within the show.

          [07:00 - 07:30] If Derek is hesitant or unresponsive, subtly withdraw from the conversation, observe him further, and consider adjusting the approach later.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
